items.title: Kitchen Garden Design
items.content_html:
Table of Contents

  • Overview
  • Goal articulation
  • Survey
    • Site systems and elements
    • Limiting factors
    • Resources
  • Miscellaneous
  • Analysis
    • Accessibility
    • Soil improvement systems
    • Permaculture Ethics
  • Decision Making
    • Kitchen garden placement
    • Raised bed layout
    • Soil Improvement systems placement
    • Other decisions
    • The final design
  • Implementation
  • Manage
  • Permaculture Principles
  • Ethics

 

Overview

Aim

To create a functional, accessible kitchen garden that will allow people of all abilities, physicalities and ages to enjoy growing edible plants.

Date

23.06.21 - 18.08.21

Location

West Yorkshire

Client

CC

Status

To be implemented

Domain

Land/nature stewardship

Principles

Framework

GoSADIM:

Goal setting, Survey, Analysis, Decision Making, Implementation, Manage
Then the additional steps of Evaluate & Tweak

By Graham Burnett at Spiral Seed  

Tools

Basemap, PASTE, DAFOR, sector analysis, overlays

Resources/support

Miro, Suncalc.org, Pinterest, Google Earth, 

Context/Scope of design

This a design about creating a functional and accessible kitchen garden to be used by a community for learning, connecting with nature, socialising and having fun

The client wanted to install a kitchen garden that would be the focus for activities for community groups.

This was the extent of the brief.  The client left it to myself and the company I was working with to create a garden that we could develop into a sustainable business.

I decided to use this opportunity to create my dream kitchen garden, and one that would be accessible to as many people as possible. I decided to use materials that had the least ecological impact and to include elements that would benefit all aspects of the environment, where possible.

The site for the kitchen garden is within a larger area designated for a bigger community gardens project. This in turn is on a very large site. There are many logistical details that need to be addressed, but these are not in the remit of this design

Goal articulation

What I want.

I would like to create a garden that;

  • produces a wide variety of fruit and vegetables
  • increases biodiversity
  • provides opportunities for people can come to learn and connect with nature/the growing process
  • is accessible for everyone and can engage a diverse range of people
  • is not only sustainable but also regenerative
  • strengthens the local community and is shaped by the local community
  • looks beautiful, to inspire and engage
  • uses environmentally friendly and organic methods - reducing waste, recycling/reusing. free from pesticides, herbicides, no peat, no dig, less fossil fuels (hand tools rather than power tools)
  • uses local resources, especially waste from on site, e.g. woodchip, leaves and grass clippings

I created a mood board on Pinterest

Survey

What I've got.

Here is Benji, helping me with the survey.

The survey was not as in-depth as I would have liked, due to the following factors;  I had a very short deadline for completing this design, accessing the site was problematic and the number of people on site to ask for more information was very limited.

You can see all my survey information on this Miro board, but Miro isn't for everyone, so I have included almost everything else below;

I  took some photos of the site and mapped them here, to indicate viewpoint A selection of the photos are below:

I used a variety of maps to indicate the geographical location

Site systems and elements

To identify what was already on the site I did the following;

I created a base map using Google Earth and Miro. You can see a much better version of this by clicking here

The area selected for the kitchen garden can be seen below, marked in turquoise. The raised bed area is marked in pink. The measurements needed for calculating the raised bed area are shown in yellow

I used the PASTE acronym to help me categorise what was within the walled garden. I only listed plants within the kitchen garden area. 

I then used the DAFOR acronym to indicate the frequency of each plant

You can read my site assessment here

Due to time constraints, I have only done a very basic sector analysis. I have not made observations myself, but have used general data available on the internet. This is sufficient for the project. 

Shade will not affect the design per se, but will influence how crops are grown, but that is not within the remit of this design. 

The greenhouse to the east of the raised bed area will cast some shade at times.

The Horse Chestnut to the south of the raised bed area will also cast some shade at times.

The trees to the west, north and east of the site will provide a windbreak, as will the walls that surround the whole site. Again, this is only really relevant to the growing of crops.

The site is fairly exposed, especially as a large number of very tall conifers have recently been cut down. These used to surround the kitchen garden site. Further developments of the site, such as the creation of a forest garden, may well provide protection. 

The site is on private land with security gates and at present there is no access to the public. This may change, depending on what happens to the site.

The hall is a Grade II listed building. The walls of the walled garden are included in this. They have fallen into disrepair but will be refurbished in 2022

 

Analysis

What the limiting factors and potential resources are.

Through analysis, our challenge is to design and establish a system where the energy needed to maintain it decreases over time, while its outputs increase  - Aranya, Permaculture Design

Limiting factors


Physical limiting factors
There is no water catchment at present.
The irrigation system is limited to one tap, which is by the wall to the east. This is a long way from where the kitchen garden has been sited.
Deer have access to the site via the car park entrance.
Squirrels, rabbits and pigeons are likely to damage crops
There are several areas that may be problematic for accessibility for those using wheelchairs/other mobility aids - different levels, trip hazards, broken paths etc.

Non - physical limiting factors
There are many unknowns - funding, community engagement logistics, local residents' reactions, communication systems.

There has been no consultation with the local community. 

There are many separate parties involved. We do not know each other very well, and the communication system is long-winded. Communication is disjointed, objectives are unclear etc.

We do not own the land.

We do not know if the design will be implemented.

At present, we do not have a tenure agreement.

No local people have been involved in this project as yet.

Resources

Woodchip and leaves from the site

Greenhouse

We may have workers from CC, in the form of young people on a training programme

ST infrastructure - accounts, email system, established business w contacts etc.

Knowledge and skills - myself and Killian have excellent skills in  growing, organisation, teaching and planning

ST will be part of the implementation and organisation/admin
It has now become clear that the land owners have a budget for this project, and they want us to submit a proposal so that they can see how much money is required.

I created this mind map to help me think about all the different elements that could be involved. Click on the mindmap to go to Miro, where you can zoom in. 

I looked at my Goal Articulation and identified the functions;

  • produces a wide variety of fruit and vegetables Food production
  • increases biodiversity Biodiversity
  • provides opportunities for people can come to learn and connect with nature/the growing process Education
  • is accessible for everyone and can engage a diverse range of people Accessibility
  • is not only sustainable but also regenerative Biodiversity
  • strengthens the local community and is shaped by the local community Community Integration
  • looks beautiful, to inspire and engage Aesthetic
  • uses environmentally friendly and organic methods - reducing waste, recycling/reusing. free from pesticides, herbicides, no peat, no dig, less fossil fuels (hand tools rather than power tools) this will be achieved via the ethic of Earth Care
  • uses local resources, especially waste from on site, e.g woodchip, leaves - this will be achieved through connecting systems

I then created a Function, Systems, Elements chart to help me see how the different elements serve the different functions. A truly resilient design would only include systems and elements that serve at least three functions. 

Accessibility

I wanted to know how we could make the site highly accessible. I collated the information and created a document using information that I found on the Thrive website. 

There were a number of different options when it came to choosing materials for the paths around the raised beds. I used a 'Strengths. Weaknesses, Needs and Challenges' chart to help me make a comparison. You can also see it here

Soil improvement systems

I looked at different composting systems; then identified waste products from on the site or locally that could be utilised.

I created a flowchart to see how different waste products from the site could be distributed.

Permaculture Ethics

unfinished

Earth Care Biodiversity will be increased through the use of a diverse number of systems and elements
  I have opted for recycled plastic planks for the raised bed as they are the most eco-friendly option
   
People Care Accessibility is a key function. education
   
Fair Share Any produce will initially go to any volunteers and if there is surplus, it can be donated to those in need. 

Decision Making

What I need to change.

Kitchen garden placement

The decision of where to place the kitchen garden was straightforward. The area next to the greenhouse previously had raised beds, so some paths are already in place. Also, it is close to the greenhouse. Putting it anywhere else would have been far more complicated and resource heavy. Use small and slow solutions #Permaculture Principle

There had been some discussion about developing the whole walled garden site. I came up with a rough idea of what could be done and this can be seen below;

There is the potential to expand the kitchen garden further, at a later date

Raised bed layout

I had to decide on the layout of the raised beds. I tried a few different configurations that can be seen here

The layout that I chose is made up of a pattern of seven beds that is repeated twice. If founding doesn't allow, just one set could be built. 

With two sets, there were two areas left to fill where plants could be grown. I decided a herb garden would be a simple element in one of the areas. Herbs will provide a crop and also food and habitat for wildlife, including pollinators. I decided to plant green manures in the other area to suppress weeds and enrich the soil. This could be developed later to grow other plants, perhaps more herbs. 

Soil Improvement systems placement

Having looked a the options I decided that all of the systems would work well on the site, as they all utilised waste that was readily available, and I anticipated that we would need a lot of compost. 

The siting for the systems changed, but the original placement can be seen here.

Other decisions

I decided to use hazel obelisks and arches to make use of the vertical, for growing crops such as peas, sweet peas and other things. 

I chose two areas for bug hotels. 

I placed the seating area by the greenhouse on an area that is fairly flat and will have a nice view of the raised beds.

The final design

Once I had made these decisions, I was able to draw a design. 

Implementation

How I will achieve the change.

The costings of the raised beds are shown below:

 

I started workplan using a Gantt chart, Because I didn't know if the project was going to go ahead, I decided not to proceed with it. If the project is approved I will continue with the planning.

Manage

How I will continue to manage and maintain this project.

The project is now on hold.

Permaculture Principles

Make the least change for the greatest effect 

More to come!

items.title: Permaculture CV
items.content_html:
Profile

Permaculture has been on my radar for twenty-five years, as someone in the community I lived in then was growing turnips in a geodesic dome, and I remember the word from then. Then I heard a bit about it when I was in Australia a couple of years later, but really only started to get interested in it when I did a bit of Wwoofing in 2015 (?). then I did the introduction workshop and that set the ball rolling.

Now I want to integrate it into my daily life, work and everything. 

Education and Training

 

  • 'Cultivating a Healthy Work Culture on your Farm' webinar | Land Worker’s Alliance | 2021
  • Rain Garden workshop | River Kennet Trust | 2021
  • Rain Planter workshop | River Kennet Trust | 2021
  • Meeting Facilitation training | Land Worker’s Alliance | 2021
  • Power, Politics and Production of Seed: An introduction to Seed Saving | 2021
  • Diploma in Applied Permaculture Design | in progress
  • Introduction to Biodynamics | BDAC (online) | 2020
  • Diploma in Horticultural Practice RHS Level 3; Distinction | 2019
  • Awarded RHS bursary for tour of prestigious UK Kitchen Gardens | 2018
  • Compact tractor certificate | 2019
  • Brush cutter and trimmer certificate | 2019
  • Hand-held hedge trimmer certificate | 2019
  • Permaculture Design Certificate | 2018
  • BTEC level 2 in Horticulture; Distinction | Shipley College | 2018
  • Introduction to Permaculture | London Permaculture Convergence | 20??
  • BA Hons Performance; Dance; 2:1 | Leeds University | 2007
  • 10 GCSEs | Millthorpe Secondary School, York | 1989 – 1994

 

Farm/Project/garden visits

Ashton Community Walled Garden, Preston | September 2021

Visited to inform my Esholt Structure design. I saw how complicated it is to run a community garden, how personalities present certain challenges, how working with a board presents issues. I only spent half a day there, but I took Paula from Sponge Tree so I had hoped that it would inspire her too.

Living Well Social Farm, Wetherby | September 2021

attended as part of the Land Workers Alliance Northern Region farm visit programme

Bowling Community Orchard

Kitchen Garden tour | 2018

Permaculture groups/events

  • Permaculture Association member since 20??
  • Active member of Diploma in Applied Permaculture Design Facebook group
  • Active member of Bradford Area Permaculture Women Facebook group
  • Buddy – 
  • Member of diploma Guild since 2020 – Manda, Aimee, Peach and now Charlotte
  • Attended weekly forum set up by Carla Moss, August ‘21
  • Attended monthly forum set up by Carla Moss, October ’21 – March ‘22
  • Attended Permaculture Association AGM 20??
  • Attended diploma accreditation event of Carla Moss
  • Attended diploma accreditation event of Helen Smith, as member of peer group
  • Attended diploma accreditation event of Yannick Naik
  • Attended diploma accreditation event of Liz Postlethwaite
  • Northern England Permaculture Convergence in 201?

 

Membership of relevant bodies

Land Workers Alliance Northern Coordinating group

Organising farm visits and other events, facilitating meetings, taking minutes, group decision making, writing content for newsletters, writing emails about events to go out to all members of Northern group

Baildon Green Community Association

Committee member, attending fortnightly meetings helping with events and working groups,

 

Seed Co-op

Myself and my partner completed a one-week work trial at the Seed Cooperative as we were applying for a job there. Sadly, we didn’t get the job, but it was a fascinating experience and we had a great time there.

I helped with seed harvesting and processing.

 

Work Experience

 

Mar 2020 – to date

Self-employed | Be Kind to Worms

Own business caring for privately owned gardens

‣ General gardening tasks including weeding, pruning, cutting back, mulching, staking, dead heading

‣ Designing borders

‣ Encouraging garden owners to take up ecological methods

 

Mar – July 2021

Grower/Harvester | Growing with Grace, Station Rd, Clapham, North Yorkshire

‣ Picking and packing organic vegetables

‣ Weeding, planting out, propagation

‣ Lead on plant sales project

 

Sept 2018 – Mar 2020

Horticultural Student | RHS Gardens Harlow Carr, Harrogate, North Yorkshire

‣ Day-to-day cultivation and maintenance tasks within the different gardening teams

‣ Planning and cultivation of vegetable plot

‣ Completion of assignments to a high standard and to deadline

‣ Delivering excellent customer service to visitors

‣ Leading apprentices and volunteers in set tasks

 

Jan 2017 – Sept 2018

Self-employed | Practically Enlightened

‣ Set up own business that offers a range of practical help on a Pay What You Want basis

‣ Provided garden maintenance, child care, house-sitting pet-sitting

 

Dec 2016 – Sept 2018

Shop assistant | Alligator Wholefoods, York, North Yorkshire

‣ Provided friendly and attentive service to customers

‣ Developed and managed the social media marketing for the company

 

May 2016 – Aug 2016

Woodland steward (Wwoof placement) | Wilderness Wood, Hadlow Down, East Sussex

‣ Maintained vegetable plot, following instructions of project manager

‣ Home-team member, assisting with events

 

Mar 2016 – May 2016 (temporary position)

Live-in carer | Private household, Marlow, Buckinghamshire

‣ Provided daily care of frail elderly lady

‣ Liaised with family members, keeping them up to date and talking through any issues

 

July 2014 – Aug 2015

Live-in carer | Private household, Marlow, Buckinghamshire

‣ Provided daily care of frail elderly couple

‣ Designed record-keeping system for care team, enabling clear communication 

 

Nov 2013 – Mar 2014

General assistant | Poulstone Court Retreat Centre, Kings Caple, Herefordshire

‣ Worked as a flexible and communicative team member

‣ Completed tasks in timely and efficient manner

 

June 2012 – Sept 2013 

Nanny | Private household, Maida Vale, London 

‣ Provided daily care of two children, boy aged 2 and girl aged 7

‣ Liaised closely with parents to ensure clear communication

 

Jan 2011 – Dec 2012 

Dance Development Officer | Epping Forest District Council, Epping, Essex

‣ Organised community dance activities for people of all ages

‣ Coordinated a large scale, intergenerational dance project 

 

Oct 2009 – Aug 2010 

Dance Development Officer | Surrey County Council, Woking, Surrey

‣ Managed a complex intergenerational dance project

‣ Collaborated with a team to organize a dance programme at an arts festival

 

Dec 2007 – Dec 2008

Freedom in Dance Project Manager | Lincolnshire Dance

‣ Managed a dance programme for older people

‣ Coordinated certificated training course for teachers

 

June 2007 – Dec 2012

Freelance Community Dance Artist | various areas of UK

‣ Co-founded Chilli Bon Bon, a dance company for adults with or without disabilities

‣ Facilitated dance activities for people of all ages and abilities

 

Achievements/Experience 

Various Wwoof placements | 2015 – 2016

Completed the Camino de Santiago, a 550-mile pilgrimage | 2015

6 years living in an intentional community, working as cook and cleaner | Somerset 1996 – 2002

 

Interests

Growing edibles on my allotment, making preserves with grown/foraged ingredients, meditation, caring for large collection of houseplants, needle-felting, writing letters, lists and Instagram posts.

items.title: Portfolio Presentation Design
items.content_html:
Table of Contents

  • Overview
  • Goals
  • Observation
  • Boundaries
  • Resources
  • Analysis
  • Design Decisions
  • Implementation
  • Maintenance
  • Evaluation
  • Permaculture Principles
  • Ethics
  • Reflection on the design process
    • What went well?
    • What was challenging?
    • Long term vision and goals
    • Next achievable steps

Overview

 

Aim
To decide how to present my diploma to make it effective, accessible and engaging

Date
28.10.21 - 09.11.21

Location
UK

Client
Myself

Status
Ongoing

Principles
Strategic

Framework
G.O.B.R.A.D.I.M.E. Goals, Observation, Boundaries, Resources, Analysis, Design, Implementation, Maintenance & Evaluation

This is a framework that was created by Heather Jo Flores. I'm using this because I haven't used it before.

Tools
Client interview, SMART goals, strengths and weaknesses analysis.

Resources/support
Killian's web design skills, other apprentice's websites for inspiration, Miro, Google Forms, Word, PowerPoint.

Context
This is a design about how I'm presenting my diploma portfolio for assessment and for a wider audience.

Having had some trouble presenting designs to people in the past, and this having quite serious consequences for the projects, I want to make sure that my designs are communicable to as many people as possible. This design will help me decide what format to use and how to approach it. I have now booked my assessment dates for my portfolio (the IPA and FPA), and this made me realise that I needed to think carefully about how to present this body of work. 

I enjoy looking at other diploma students' design portfolios and I would like to share my own, but would only be happy to do so if my work was of a standard that I was happy with, in  a format that I'm happy with.

Goals

I used SMART goals to pinpoint what I wanted. I created this with a Miro template.

I need to fix a couple of errors on this

Observation

I used a tool called Client Interview to find out what I was wanting to get out of my portfolio design. Yes, I interviewed myself.

Boundaries

Time is a boundary, I don't have time to be faffing - I just need a simple format that each design fits into for presentation. 

The fact that the designs need to be clear and concise, accessible and engaging is a boundary, because it means that I can't ramble. I need to be careful that I don't drift off subject. 

I don't want to spend a lot of money.

Resources

  • Access to the portfolios of numerous diploma students, via their websites
  • PowerPoint
  • Word
  • Excel
  • Miro
  • Body of work - designs in various stages of completion
  • My partner is a web site technician...

Analysis

I use Miro for a lot of my design work. It's an online whiteboard platform that is designed to allow teams to collaborate. Boards seem to be able to expand into infinity,  it's a very visual tool, and as my thinking is non-linear, it helps me to keep track of my ideas. I find it indispensable for designing. Because I love it so much, I wondered if I could use it to present my portfolio.

I did a strengths and weaknesses analysis to get a better picture;

It was quite clear that a website would be better. I hadn't even considered that my partner could make me a website. That is how fixated I was on using Miro. If anyone wants to get me a Christmas/birthday present, subscription to Miro? Just sayin'...

Design Decisions

I will;

  • present my portfolio on a website
  • use different methods for creating content - including Miro, Word and PowerPoint, as well as others, but then each design will be displayed in same format on the website
  • continue working on designs and add them to the website when they're complete
  • write a website brief
  • set a writing style with rules

Implementation

Task When
Give Killian the brief  29.10.21
Killian to set up website   07.11.21
As I complete a design I will gather together all elements from on Miro/Word/PowerPoint etc and create pages on website  as and when
Add designs to website when they are ready - one a week until IPA then as and when until FPA (timeline also in ALP) as and when
Publish Website once first design goes up, so that my tutor can see it  07.11.21

Maintenance

As the site is static it requires less maintenance.

By uploading designs according to the timeline in my ALP, I will be maintaining the website regularly.

Technical changes may need to be made to keep website secure and functioning efficiently on modern browsers.

May need to update in line with legal compliance, e.g GDPR, cookies etc.

Evaluation

Have I met my goals?
1. Work out how to present my diploma
Yes, I have definitely done this. I have a template for the presentation of each of my designs. The design process worked well to meet this goal as it helped me to see things from different perspectives. It meets my long and short term needs because I now have a website to present my portfolio and I can add a section for my gardening business. I didn't quite keep to the deadline but I'm still pleased with the turnaround.  As you can see, the website is up and running!

I wanted to have a low carbon website. One option for this was to go with a low carbon website company. However, website designers aim to create a fast, efficient websites to  achieve high performance. Low carbon is a by-product of this. For this reason, I feel that I have met my goal. 

2. Do a speedy design
I had given myself a day to complete it, and I did whizz through it, but I had to go back and do a lot of tweaking because I'd missed stuff out. Even though I missed my deadline, it served my need to get a design done quickly, to progress the project. It helped me keep focussed and concise. 

3. Make it visually engaging
I will have to wait for feedback, but personally, I like it! 

4. Allow anyone to understand my designs
Again, I will have to wait until I get some feedback

Insert charts created with Google Forms.

Feedback so far:

wooof wooof woof, woof wooof. Woof woof woooof.

- Benji, Jessie's dog

Permaculture Principles


Strategic Principles

Feed what you want to grow 

I would like permaculture to grow - hopefully my website will help people to understand what it is, and inspire them to incorporate it into their own lives.

Eventually, I want to grow the website into a platform for my business, so I'm creating something that will serve my short term and long term goals.

I also really love techy stuff, and this design process will increase my skill set. 

Use edges

Clients looking for garden design will also see my permaculture designs, and therefore may learn something about permaculture and want to know more, perhaps even have it used in their gardens.

Make it beautiful

I intend to create a visually pleasing and cohesive website. 

Use onsite resources

Killian! I hadn't thought of enlisting his help, as I usually enjoy building websites myself, but as he offered and I'm short of time, I decided to run with it.


Work Where it Counts 

Rather than creating a second-rate presentation on Miro, developing the website idea is putting energy where it is most beneficial, and most accessible.


Invest Wisely

I am investing money into my website, but it is a sound investment as it will also support my business in the future. I am also using my time wisely, because trying to make Miro be something it isn't actually designed for would be a lot of work.

Be Realistic

Trying to get Miro to do everything was unrealistic, and also, I need to be realistic about how much time and energy I have for doing this work

Ethics

People Care

Self care; I'm making my diploma journey smoother by creating a well-thought out presentation process, This should mean that I experience as little stress as possible in the run up to completing my portfolio.

Earth Care

I intend to have a website that has a low carbon footprint.

Fair Share

Sharing designs with people online, widening the understanding of Permaculture.

Reflection on the design process

What went well?

I genuinely had not considered getting Killian to set up a website for me, even though it may have been obvious to anyone else. Through the process I let go of my fixation with Miro, and with my need to do everything and conceded that I ought to let him help me!

I'm really pleased with the website, I'm confident that it has met my needs.

Also, Killian found a way to do it all for free, without adverts! 

What was challenging?

Choosing the right tools and understanding which elements of the design process fitted into which design step. Analysis still confuses me.

I did a SWOC analysis but it didn't work, it was too basic a concept so I just did a strengths and weaknesses analysis instead, which was appropriate to the task. That was really useful to see, I am starting to see how the finding the right tool for the right task is important.

Long term vision and goals

I hope to have my full portfolio of ten designs uploaded onto the website in time for my final assessment, which is on the twenty-second of February. 

At that stage, I can begin to develop the website in order to promote my gardening business and to also present the design work that I will do after the accreditation. 

I would like to help other diploma students with their web sites, and by that I mean get Killian to help them with their websites!

Next achievable steps

  • Get feedback about the site and complete the evaluation
  • Share with my tutor for my first assessment
  • I hope to have five of my designs completed and uploaded onto the website in time for my interim portfolio assessment, the deadline for this is the first of December, 2021

items.title: Hello!
items.content_html:
Welcome to my design portfolio for the Diploma in Applied Permaculture Design

 

“When you are a Bear of Very Little Brain, and you Think of Things, you find sometimes that a Thing which seemed very Thingish inside you is quite different when it gets out into the open and has other people looking at it.”
― A.A. Milne, Winnie-the-Pooh

So here you are in the place where I have put some Things that were very Thingish inside me. Well, hurrah, they are now out in the open for you to look at. I hope you like them. 

If you feel like letting me know what you think of my new website, you could fill in this form here. That would be very helpful and I will be hugely grateful.
